Acer Aspire 1524 WLMi
Open up /etc/default/acpi-support in a text editor.
Uncomment the line: ACPI_SLEEP=true.

I'm not sure if you then have to reload something, or if so how to do so.  For sure it will take effect after a reboot, but of course that can be annoying, so maybe just write this down now for later trail.
After your next boot, try the key sequence to suspend, or call /etc/acpi/sleep.sh
If that doesn't work, try editing /boot/grub/menu.lst
Find the kernel entry, and add pci=noacpi acpi_sleep=s3_bios to it.
Test that out.  If still no luck, s1 instead of s3 might work, but use more power.
Okay, now that's all I have.  Have you tried any of that already?
See http://acpi.sourceforge.net/documentation/sleep.html for an explanation of the S-states you saw before in /proc/acpi/sleep
